April is National Sexual Assault Awareness and Prevention Month. Watching soaps today, alone, would make you question, 1 â€“ whether writers were aware of the significance of this month, 2 â€“ if they would care if they were aware of it. According to RAINN, every 2 minutes someone in the U.S. is sexually assaulted. Click the RAINN symbol to learn more about SAAP month, and to find events taking place in your local area. Today, on almost every soap left on air, a woman was nearly sexually assaulted, emotionally assaulted, or physically assaulted â€“ almost none for the sake of furthering a discussion about sexual and other violent assaults. Almost all for the sake of â€˜entertainmentâ€™. Check the ratings, writers, we â€“ your primarily female audience, are not amused or entertained by such storylines.

1. Days of Our lives. Iâ€™ve thought of EJ as a coward for quite a long time. Todayâ€™s episode just made things a heck of a lot worse. If your father is a murderous psychopath and youâ€™re quickly following in his footsteps, then it makes sense that you donâ€™t care to protect your partner in crime from your fatherâ€™s tyrannical wrath. It makes you appear to be less human, as well. Too busy trying to cover his own arse, EJ has made no moves to stop others from thinking of Anna as a vile kidnapper who tormented a young infant girl for months after sheâ€™d already lost the only mother sheâ€™d ever known. If you were watching todayâ€™s episode, you witnessed Stefano Dimera, EJâ€™s father, physically assault his former daughter-in-law, his deceased sonâ€™s wife. Tony might have killed Stefano for slapping his wife.

The excuse is supposed to be, Iâ€™m sure, that Stefano had no idea that Anna wasnâ€™t alone in kidnapping his granddaughter when he slapped her. My response? WHO CARES!?!?! She as alone, half dressed and defenseless against him and the goons he brought with him. That scene was heartbreaking from beginning to end. It was in fact EJ, the childâ€™s father, who concocted the scheme and convinced Anna to become his partner in crime. It was his son EJ, who got the â€˜brightâ€™ idea to cover the childâ€™s clothing in blood and make everyone think the infant had been murdered. Will Stefano slap him across the face? Will he have his son dragged off with threats of death? Is that behavior reserved only for women â€˜who have it comingâ€™?

While EJ sat home, basking in the glow of being complimented for being a â€˜great dadâ€™, Anna was being slapped around, manhandled by Stefanoâ€™s goons, and had to plead for her life, as Stefano promised her that she would not be alive much longer. DAYS has done a lot of things right, but this was dead wrong and made it clear how parasitic the Dimera menâ€™s relationships with women are. EJ professes love, two children later, to the woman he raped at gunpoint, and while he sat with her trying to convince her he was a new man, Anna faced violence and certain death.

2. The Bold and the Beautiful. I watched the last 10 minutes of the show, today â€“ apparently ten minutes too many! It was a continuation of Donna Logan Forrester being treated as if she was disposable by her husband, Eric Forrester. This follows an earlier discussion in which he screamed at her in front of his ex wife and his former sister-in-law (both of whom have attacked Donna physically and verbally). Earlier heâ€™d faulted Donna for never being on his side â€“ a full-throated lie. Heâ€™s clearly â€˜finishedâ€™ with Donna and finds excuses to scream and yell at her, including faulting Donna for her brother-in-lawâ€™s partnership with his WILLING ex-wife, who helped weaken his company before Bill Spencer bought it out from from under him. Eric accepts no responsibility for being a lousy businessperson. He also gives Donna ZERO credit for being willing to deceive her own sister to help him get his company back. He screams at her, demeans her, and then she returns home to beg for his forgiveness for not being tolerant enough of his needs. If she was a friend of mine in a marriage like that, I would be advising her on thinking about how to get out of it, or at least how to protect herself from a man like Eric Forrester.

3. One Life to Live. Schuyler Joplin has been just about as perfect a man as one can be in daytime. Heâ€™s thoughtful, loving, kind, and patientâ€¦ which means that when he had to be torn down to prop the showâ€™s resident snooze producing couple â€“ the writers took the lowest possible route to try to make him unlikable to fans. His soap day started with him being a loving father who only wanted the best for his child. He finds out the child heâ€™s been loving isnâ€™t his and just a few hours later heâ€™s holding Gigi Morasco hostage at gunpoint, trying to force her to undress so they can have sex and he could prove to her that they still have a special relationship. He doesnâ€™t want to be alone.

Pretty.Damned.Pathetic.

Soaps use to write rape storylines to sway fansâ€™ sympathy in the direction of â€˜bad girls who needed redeemingâ€™. Now they use rape as a way of trying to sway fansâ€™ ire at male characters they want to get rid of â€” most of the time. Sometimes they decide that the rapist isnâ€™t all that bad and try to redeem him or try to get the audience to accept his attempt to get his victim to fall in love with him. Itâ€™s that sort of clumsy and careless storytelling that makes soap fans ashamed of the genre.

4. General Hospital. Kristina, after ignoring Ethanâ€™s pleas to not allow the entire town, most especially her murderous mob father, believe that heâ€™d beaten her up- as he was innocent â€“ was beaten again today by her boyfriend, Kiefer. Iâ€™d watched DAYSâ€™ Anna being slapped around, DAYSâ€™ Sami talking about her lovelife with her rapist, OLTLâ€™s Gigi held at gunpoint and potentially raped, BnBâ€™s Donna beg forgiveness for being treated poorly, and then Kristina. I am emotionally drained and most especially because itâ€™s clear that daytime writers still donâ€™t get it.

As usual, the storyline hasnâ€™t been about this poor teenage girl who is being harmed, itâ€™s about the adults around her â€“ her mother who took the time to run down her attacker with her car while on the way to the hospital to get help for Kristina, her angry mob boss father, Ethan -the wrongfully accusedâ€¦ but very little about the survivor.

Iâ€™m hoping weâ€™ll see more of Kristina, in therapy to learn that itâ€™s not her fault sheâ€™s been attacked, or that weâ€™ll get to see her confront Kiefer and make him realize how badly heâ€™s hurt her. As Iâ€™ve written about before, it would be best to see HIM in therapy â€“ helping him figure out why heâ€™s so violent towards women.

Soaps do a lot with the â€˜assaultâ€™ part, nothing much with the â€˜preventionâ€™. Were women victims of assault and violence on the other two soaps? Probably, Iâ€™m just glad I missed it â€“ Iâ€™ve had more than my fill in just a single day. Itâ€™s depressing.

No, not â€˜Basterdsâ€™, thatâ€™s Tarantinoâ€™s deal. The IBâ€™s Iâ€™m (lovingly) referring to are the daytime writers who have yet to give up on trying to pull one over on the fans!

One Life to Live

1. Iâ€™d appreciate it if someone would explain to me why Cole and Starr (of â€˜Weâ€™re Cole and Starrâ€™ fame) would think it was â€˜okâ€™ to involve Starr in Coleâ€™s â€˜21 Jump Streetâ€˜ drug operation. From there, â€œStoleâ€ proved that neither will ever be a member of the Llanview brain trust! I was stupefied after they involved their innocent defenseless baby to give â€˜credibilityâ€™ to Coleâ€™s cover. Why didnâ€™t they stage a break up before having Cole go â€˜undercoverâ€™? Why not have Starr and child leave town for a while? Oh, I get it! â€œThere is no â€˜Starr and Cole, theyâ€™re fictional â€“ THEY didnâ€™t do itâ€! â€œIt was all the writers doingâ€. That wonâ€™t stop me from cringing whenever Starr and Cole are on. The longer this pairing goes on, the weaker the writing for them becomes. Itâ€™s increasingly more difficult it is to like them and I find myself resenting the airtime theyâ€™ve stolen from veteran characters. The characters are consistently placed in storylines that are â€˜too adultâ€™ for them and the integrity of the storyline suffers as a result.

2. I donâ€™t care who Rexâ€™s father isâ€¦ itâ€™s dragged on too long without enough plot points in between to keep me curious. Now Iâ€™m just annoyed every time the topic comes up. Rex is a freakinâ€™ private investigator. He must really suck at his job if he canâ€™t figure this one out. Isnâ€™t it just a tad bit odd that he can figure out that Tea has some deep dark secrets, but canâ€™t find his own father? Itâ€™s also odd that he canâ€™t keep up with Stacyâ€™s mustache twirling machinations!

I love Stacy Morascoâ€¦ oh yeah, I said LOVE, but itâ€™s evident that while her engine is on, thereâ€™s no one behind the wheel. If SHE can outsmart Rex, time and again, heâ€™s working with a single digit IQ. Iâ€™m going to hate myself later for admitting this, but Iâ€™m thrilled at the thought of a Gigi Schuyler pairing and a Rex and Stacy pairing â€“ if only because Stacy will make sure Rex stays miserable for a LONG time. What irony that Ilene Kristen who played Ryanâ€™s Hopeâ€™s scheming bad girl (Delia Reid Ryan) could become the onscreen mother-in-law of a similar character!

3. Fish and Kyle. Daytime writers seem to believe that all gays have a traumatic coming out experience. While it may be a difficult moment for some, will OLTL writers ever give the audience a gay character who isnâ€™t closeted and terrified of coming out? I lived through the Daniel Colson storyline. I would have much rather had Fish avoid Kyle because he gave his heart and soul to Kyle in college and Kyle cheated, lied, and was generally unconcerned about anyone but himself. Thatâ€™s VERY consistent with the scheming, lying, blackmailing Kyle we were introduced to.

At some point, writers, can we please just have gay characters who are actually HAPPY with their lives, and not afraid that their friends and family will turn on them? Am I watching too much Miami Social? (Yeah, I should be ashamed of admitting that too! That cast of real life characters puts the â€˜superâ€™ in superficial!)

General Hospital

1. Oh those sneaky GH writers! Theyâ€™ve pulled a fast one. Every FBI agent, or undercover cop, ever sent to â€˜take Sonny downâ€™ ended up falling for Jasonâ€™s pecs, Spinelliâ€™s wit, or the magic of Sonnyâ€™s pecker (Hannah, Reese). So how have the writers topped themselves? HA! Itâ€™s the fruit of Sonnyâ€™s loins (product of the pecker) who is now being sent to take him down! Marked improvement, writers, reallyâ€¦ only not! Itâ€™s a given that Dante Falconeri wonâ€™t end up carrying Sonnyâ€™s child and wouldnâ€™t want to even if he could, thank the soapgods. Unfortunately thereâ€™s no guarantee that Dante wonâ€™t go the way of every cop/agent before him and end up loving his papa, Sonny, so much that he turns on his profession to protect him.

Even though Iâ€™m having a hard time buying Dante as Olivia and Sonnyâ€™s kid, Iâ€™ll suspend disbelief if Dante is allowed to put the mob storyline to bed, rather than climb into bed with the mob when all is revealed. (I canâ€™t be the only one who thinks that Dominic Zamprognaâ€™s Dante, looks more like Oliviaâ€™s older brother than her son! David Lago would have been a much better choice given the characterâ€™s supposed age, but since Iâ€™m enjoying DZ in the role, I can live with it). Letâ€™s hope that the revelation that Sonny is his father will mean that Dante becomes more determined than ever to shut Sonnyâ€™s operation down. If Dante doesnâ€™t actually signal the end of the reign of the mob boys, GH is doomed. The writers either have to send them to prison (wonâ€™t happen) or have them leave their lives of crime (canâ€™t see this happening either), but things canâ€™t go on as they are.

2. Nikâ€¦ calling Emily Rebecca a â€˜whoreâ€™ and â€˜slutâ€™ and repeatedly making reference to how easily she â€˜spreads her legsâ€™â€¦ just lovelyâ€¦ As much as I despise Rebecca, I would have cheered her on for slapping â€˜Prince Nikolasâ€™ out of his shoes, thank you very much! If I recall, Nik was as â€˜sluttyâ€™ as Rebecca. She wanted money, he wanted an Emily substitute and tried to give it up to her much sooner than she was willing to give herself to him.

Why do I feel the need to shower after watching GH?

The Bold and The Beautiful

Speaking of showers, did anyone watch KKLâ€™s Brooke and HTâ€™s Taylor mud wrestling scene? Obviously, I didnâ€™t, but as I understand it, the actresses (their characters) took a â€˜mud bathâ€™ to cleanse their toxins and a fight broke out between the characters.

Whatâ€™s up next? The Brooke and Taylor accidentally fall into a vat of jello and begin fighting?

A pillow fight breaks out and they â€˜accidentallyâ€™ start ripping each otherâ€™s shirts open?

Tsk, tsk, tsk, The Bold and The Beautiful writers.

Letâ€™s rid ourselves of all of the bad editors! (if you donâ€™t mind the turn of phrase).Most of what took place on OLTL this past week pleasantly surprised me. Even my well worn remote would like to take this moment to thank the writers for relief. It pretty much had the week off with One Life, since I donâ€™t remember hitting FF once this week. The only big shocker for me this past week were several pretty lousy editing choices, one in particular. Iâ€™ll get to that in a moment.

Soap-heaven help me, I still like John and Marty. The only thing thatâ€™s harder to take than a dark and brooding John McBain is John McBain in love. â€˜Happyâ€™ John and â€˜Broodingâ€™ John are pretty much one in the same. Itâ€™s just at times tough to watch a man who SHOULD be filled with joy behave like a man whose problems could all be solved with the help of a good laxative. Wardrobe, could you PLEASE at least put on a brightly colored shirt under his dark suit jacket and dark coat, to go along with his dark pants and dark shoes so that we know the difference between Brooding John and Joyous John? Thanks!

Johnâ€™s reaction to Marty as she flashed back on her the manipulated-rape sex with Todd was a reminder that there are soap writers who still realize that itâ€™s so much easier for fans to root for good men â€“ we get so few of them in daytime. Many of us still love men who are sensitive to the needs of others, rather than focus on themselves and their own pain. LOVED that moment when John reminded Marty that he was always willing to wait for her â€“ sheâ€™s worth it. LOVED that the writers didnâ€™t follow that scene up with John immediately running to someone else to flirt with or have sex with while Marty was working on her recovery.

The only thing that made the scene even remotely awkward was watching Blair seduce Todd at the same time Marty had difficulty being touched by John because of Toddâ€™s assault of her. If the writers wanted to make some of us squeamish about Todd and Blair, job well done. Otherwise? Bad editing job on this one. It made Todd and Blair seem completely disconnected from the world around them, belligerently insular. They seemed to not care about how much damage had been done to others in their time apart.

Blair, who was disgusted by Toddâ€™s treatment of Marty, seems to have absolutely no qualms about his actions, now. She was disgusted enough before to want to keep his children from him. Now? She canâ€™t keep her hands off of him.

I would much rather have had long soulful talks between the two rather than strip scenes and â€œshame-filledâ€ sex. The problem with the writing for the once magnificent Todd and Blair is that that the writers donâ€™t seem invested in having them break the inch deep-mile wide pattern theyâ€™ve established as part of their courtship. OLTL writers have seem to always bank on the hard work of Kassie DePaiva and Trevor St. John in winning back fans to the â€˜Todd and Blair corner to bring romance back to the show. I think theyâ€™ll have to reconsider, this time. Too much damage has been done and an instant reunion most likely wonâ€™t give them the bump theyâ€™re looking for. How instant is instant in their case? Todd/Blair reunions can be summarized by the following dialogue:

â€œYou hurt meâ€ (Todd to Blair, Blair to Todd, it doesnâ€™t matter).

â€œIâ€™m sorryâ€ (Todd to Blair, Blair to Todd, it doesnâ€™t matter)

â€œStay away from meâ€ (Todd to Blair, Blair to Todd, it doesnâ€™t matter)

â€œYou donâ€™t mean thatâ€ (Todd to Blair, Blair to Todd, it doesnâ€™t matter)

They have sexâ€¦ AND SCENE!

Where is the discussion about what they want and why they want it? What about some insight into why they dragged Marty and John into their psychodrama? How about some part humorous/part dramatic couples counseling for them? What about real consideration about Teaâ€™s feelings? Itâ€™s bad enough that Todd cheated on Tea after she put everything on the line for him, her life included, but he then lied and said that it meant nothing that heâ€™d had sex with Blair. If it wasnâ€™t a lie that having sex with Blair meant nothing to him? It makes his actions even worse. The writers rubbed salt in fansâ€™ wounds by having Todd coldly state to Blair that he was leaving her to go after Tea â€˜because sheâ€™s worth itâ€™.

Hells bells, people, you know that despite Teaâ€™s fault, Iâ€™m a fan of the goddess of grand bitchery but for TODD to state who is â€˜worthyâ€™ and who isnâ€™t? Well that just burns my grits. I would have loved watching Blair get up off the chaise lounge and slap Todd back to his infancy (which would finally allow his external state match his internal state)! Marty, Tea, Blair, his sister Viki, and even his own daughter, Starrâ€¦ just how many women in Llanview are going to end up emotionally scarred thanks to this guy? Taking Todd down the dark road for the sake of pimping â€œStarr and Coleâ€ is a decision that still haunts this show. The writers havenâ€™t been able to find their â€˜Todd mojoâ€™ and get anything right with this character since then.

Despite the detour and bad editing, I enjoy Marty and John.

What else was there to love?

1. Greg turned out to not be a big a jerk as he originally seemed. I liked that he experienced pangs of guilt about running out on Destiny and realizing that heâ€™d hurt her with his actions. Lovinâ€™ the OLTL writers for giving us this little family. Itâ€™s so unconventional and I canâ€™t wait to see where they go next. Donâ€™t make me eat those words, writers.

2. I uhâ€¦ liked Destiny last week. If youâ€™re shocked, imagine how I feel. Iâ€™m starting to see what the casting directors saw in this kid when they cast her. It will be interesting to see where the friendship between Destiny and Matthew goes.

3. I uhâ€¦ liked Starr last week. Still in shock here! The discussion between Starr, Cole, and Jessica was so rational and thoughtful, I have to classify it as the high point of my soap watching week! Alderson held her own in scenes with Buddy and Williamson. Scene chewing is not her thing so this emotionally low-key scene felt genuine and believable. Both Jess and Cole realized that they had to forgive others as they needed to be forgiven. For a brief and shining moment, I felt that I could honestly tell my friends who donâ€™t know that I watch soaps about the show â€¦ well done, writers, well done! It was good enough for prime timeâ€¦ ğŸ˜‰ Ouch?

4. Wish I could give a crap about the Stacy storyline, but I donâ€™t. I donâ€™t even care who Rexâ€™s father is any moreâ€¦ just.not.interested!

While Starr moved one step closer to being a â€˜real momâ€™, Gigi took a step back for me. (Wait, Iâ€™m getting to itâ€¦ thereâ€™s something I like about this storyline, hang on)â€¦ It was odd to watch her encourage Shaneâ€™s hatred of Aunt Stacy no matter how much of a low life Stacy has been.

I had to wonder if there wasnâ€™t a unconscious attempt to warn fans about the perils of being a young mother â€“ since it appears that theyâ€™re avoiding that â€˜lessonâ€™ of young parenthood with Starr and Cole. Gigi applauding Shaneâ€™s comic book character (skanky Stacy? Sleazy Stacy?) REEKED of an immature mother dragging her child into her babyâ€™s daddy drama. SO, hereâ€™s what I loved

A â€“ That the â€˜secretâ€™ is finally out in the open. I was tired of this storyline about a month before it began (damn you spoilers!)

B â€“ That thereâ€™s a possibility of a Schuyler-Gigi pairing â€“ the actors have an amazing onscreen chemistry. Rex and Gigi have been terminally cute. Schuyler and Gigi have the potential to be hot!. Having Rex sleep with Stacy and lie about it after treating Gigi like such dirt for so long makes Rex and Gigi a dead pairing for me, for now. No matter how many things didnâ€™t add up, Rex refused to believe the truth and painted the Scarlett â€˜Aâ€™ on Gigiâ€™s chest â€“ clearly tempted to use her own blood to do so. Let Big Rex, and little Rex, sit on the sidelines and watch Gigi happy with someone else for a while.

5 â€“ Iâ€™ve never been much of a Bo and Nora fanâ€¦ but theyâ€™re reeling me in. Poor Clintâ€¦ Sorry guy, I think I want to see a Bo and Nora reunion. Clint and Nora seem to have been killing time for a while now. Send Clint home to Viki (sorry Charlie!)

Why is it that the best â€˜soapâ€™ moments donâ€™t come from daytime soaps at all? If you got goosebumps reading the subject header, you remember the infamous scene from â€˜Laceâ€™ in which celebrated wild child, Lili, confronts Pagan, Maxine, and Judy. The latter three have been best friends since their days at boarding school, so much so that they hid a pregnancy â€“ refusing to tell which of the three was pregnant. Together they placed the child for adoption. Lili is that child. While adopted by a lovely couple, Liliâ€™s childhood was miserable following their untimely death. She was forced to â€˜surviveâ€™ in the most unlikely of ways. Though now incredibly wealthy and successful, Lili is equally angry at the three for having abandoned her (they believed she was killed in the war along with her adoptive parents). Lili sets each of the three women up to lose everything they hold dear, unless they answer the long-held hair raising questionâ€¦ one of entertainmentâ€™s soapiest moments is found 1:28 into the video:

You really want to know which â€˜bitchâ€™ is it, donâ€™t you? Fineâ€¦ here you go:

Where is the same level of camp/drama/intrigue in daytime? Where is the lovely but infuriating clever ingenue who steals your heart, but makes you lose your cool all at the same time? She is not alone in being missing in action in the soap genre. Daytime is woefully short in offering two types of characters that have typically driven soaps in the past:

1. Empowered women. The empowered womanâ€™s motto is, â€˜If they screw with you, pay them back tenfoldâ€™. The empowered woman in daytime is unapologetic for being smart and in control of her own destiny. She does not suffer fools gladly. She knows what she wants and sheâ€™s not afraid to go after it. Her strength is a true strength, and not psychotic and controlling behaviors reinterpreted as strength â€“ as with bat crap crazy BnBâ€™s Stephanie Forrester and GHâ€™s Helena Cassadine.

Sheâ€™s equipped to stand her ground in the boardroom, in her romantic relationships, and in all other aspects of her empowered life. Take, for example, OLTLâ€™s Rachel Gannon. Sheâ€™s a second generation empowered woman (as far as we know). Daughter of the legendary ass-kicking Nora Gannon Buchanan, Rachel fought a drug habit, served time in prison, is now a drug treatment counselor, and a woman slowly falling in love with a good man â€“ the damned sexy and cuddly Shaun Evans .. who has a rich, powerful, sleaze for a brother. You can see where this is going, canâ€™t you? Hang on a minute.

Empowered women still exist, theyâ€™re just often revamped to play â€˜weakâ€™ and â€˜whinyâ€™ women who have to beg forgiveness when theyâ€™re mistreated by the men in their lives, or by others. If theyâ€™re not completely destroyed, theyâ€™re placed on the backburner once daytime writers decide that theyâ€™ve had enough with all the â€˜gritâ€™ and â€˜courageâ€™ and they replace her with knuckle-drooling counterpart â€“ weak women whose claim to fame is compliance and acquiescence â€“ deference to the mindless soap male. Itâ€™s why Iâ€™m sure that in short order, Rachel Gannon will fall for the sleazy brother, Dr. Gregory Evans. Sheâ€™ll want to â€˜saveâ€™ him from himself, and sheâ€™ll hurt sweetheart Shaun in the process.

The dialogue that follows? â€œWe didnâ€™t mean to hurt you!â€ â€¦ â€œIt just happenedâ€â€¦.â€ If I could take it all backâ€â€¦ and then the years of affairs, maltreatment, excuses, and bitter triangles in which sheâ€™ll have to fight off Gregâ€™s other â€˜great loveâ€™ beginsâ€¦ for you dear soap fans, not for me. As Iâ€™ve taken the BnB off my playlist, the OLTL is soon to follow should the storyline play out as it seems. What is it with OLTL and the siblings/shared lovers storylines? Layla/Cristian/Evangeline â€“ Bo/Nora/Clint â€“ Stacy/Rex/Gigi, and now, most likely, Shaun/Rachel/Gregory.

2. The Vixen. Unlike the empowered woman, she fights from a position of fear, anger, and insecurity. Her motto is â€˜Get them before they get youâ€™. Sheâ€™s more likely to wreak havoc and create hell in the lives around her and not because sheâ€™s necessarily evil, but more so because she doesnâ€™t know any other way of existing. DAYSâ€™ Melanie comes closest to a real live â€˜bad girlâ€™ in the mold of the daytime classic over-the-top troubled vixens, but I need more.

Remember GHâ€™s Lucy Coe when she was first introduced? Oh.Dear.Soapgod. Who could have seen that one coming? That Lucy was involved with bad boy Kevin was a givenâ€¦ it was clear that the mousy librarian was protecting him. That the â€˜mousyâ€™ librarian wasnâ€™t mousy at all, but a studded collar short from being a dominatrix? SAY WHAT? No one I knew who watched soaps then had ever seen anything like it. Sadly, I suspect weâ€™ll never see anything as off the wall wonderful as Lucy Coe again, not in daytime (OH, and SHAME ON YOU, GH. In a recent interview, Lynn Herring (Lucy Coe) reveals that she made it clear to TPTB that she was open to reprising the roleâ€¦ they werenâ€™t interested. GHâ€™s loss is As The World Turnsâ€™ gain.

Iâ€™d hoped that OLTLâ€™s Stacy would become Lucy-esque, she had such potential â€“ but the writers took it one step twenty steps too far. Not only did Stacy drug and try to seduce Rex Balsom, the object of her obsession, her sisterâ€™s fiance, and father of her only nephew (pretty tame for daytime vixens, however), she went as far as allowing her sister, Gigi, to believe that she would allow Gigiâ€™s son, Shane, die unless her sister turned Rex over to her. Thatâ€™s pretty psychotic for a daytime vixen. If there was ever anything to root for as far as Stacy was concerned, that storyline killed it. Had the writers had Stacy fake being the donor, with Roxy and Kyleâ€™s help as she was already doing, Stacy as a vixen could have survived. She could have then played off of Rexâ€™s gratitude to slowly seduce him away as Gigi was heavily focused on Shaneâ€™s recovery. The writers could have set a trusting Gigi up to ask Rex to play â€˜nurse maidâ€™ to her recovering sister. Allowing a mother to believe that you would let her son die, for a roll in the hay? Bad. When the childâ€™s mother is your own sister? EVIL.

Without itâ€™s heroic empowered women and mischief making vixens, daytime has me tuning elsewhere for interesting characters (real or fictional).

While all of daytime has me rolling my eyes lately, OLTL â€“ in particular wins the â€˜shut your pie holeâ€™ awards.
